Collectivism keep its promise to workmen, a speedy national bankruptcy is inevitable. Let us suppose, then, that it will not keep its promise. How will κ it replace and maintain, not to say augment, its capital? It has deliberately stopped and choked up all the existent sources of capitalisation, all the motives and inducements to economy and invest· ment on the part of individuale. It will not allow individuals even if they save to use their savings as capital. It can only, therefore, find capital for itself by some process of the nature of taxation. But this must be a poor and shallow source com-, pared with those which contribule to the formation of capital at present. Men who have the means and opportunity of forming capital are generally anxious to capitalise as much as possible ; but those who have the means and opportunity of paying taxes are as generally anxious to pay as little asw possible.
